./.title: Welcome!
./.body:
Welcome!
Welcome to the Mediarithmics automation documentation.
Here you will learn how to make the most of the Mediarithmics and its features.
Use the table of content to the left and the search bar on top to find what you're looking for.

automations/what-are-automations/.title: What are automations?
automations/what-are-automations/.body:
What are automations?
Here is a definition for automation:

The process of removing human intervention and relying on machines to coordinate repetitive tasks.

But to better understand what this is about, let's consider the following example.
Let's say you own an online shop and you have customers adding products to their carts, and you want to target those who do not complete their purchase.
Sure, you could manually extract a list of customers everyday and input that list into your email marketing software, but that would get real tedious real fast.
It would be really great if every time a customer adds a product to the cart, an automatic trigger would send an email if eventually there is no purchase. In a nutshell, that's what automation is about.
You can find automations in the Automations menu item on the left of your screen.

automations/what-are-automations/automat.title: Automation type 1
automations/what-are-automations/automat.body:
Automation type 1
Super nouveau type automation.
Titre 1

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: The key components of an automation
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
The key components of an automation
Here you will learn about the key components of an automation:

Triggers
Actions
Flow control
Exit conditions

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: Triggers
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
Triggers
The trigger is what will make a user enter an automation. Each automation can have one and only one trigger.
Once you enter the automation builder, you will be asked to choose the type of trigger your want for your automation:

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: React to an event
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
React to an event
If you choose "React to an event" as the trigger for your automation, the automation will be triggered each time a user causes a specified event.
The configuration will allow you to specify which events should trigger this automation:

In the Advanced view, you can also add field conditions, for instance if you want to trigger your automation only with events taking place after a certain date, ...

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: On segment entry
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
On segment entry
If you choose "On segment entry" as the trigger for your automation, the automation will be linked to segment calculation and be triggered each time a user enters a specific segment.
The configuration will allow you to specify which segment should trigger this automation:

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: On segment exit
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
On segment exit
If you choose "On segment exit" as the trigger for your automation, the automation will be linked to segment calculation and be triggered each time a user leaves a specific segment.
The configuration will allow you to specify which segment should trigger this automation:

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: Actions
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
Actions
Actions are just what they mean: actions. You can find the list of actions in the Automation Components drawer on the right side of the builder.

Simply drag and drop the action you want to add in the path of your automation.

You'll then be asked to configure the action you've just added.
You can edit the configuration for an action or remove it simply by clicking on it.

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: Flow control
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
Flow control
Flow control components let you alter the natural flow of an automation. You can find the list of flow control components in the Automation Components drawer on the right side of the builder.

Simply drag and drop the component you want to add in the path of your automation.

You'll then be asked to configure the component you've just added.
You can edit the configuration for a component or remove it simply by clicking on it.

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: Split
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
Split
The Split flow control component lets you divide the automation flow into several branches.
For instance, if you choose to divide your flow into 2 branches, then 1 out of 2 users will go on branch A, and the other will go on branch B.

You can configure the number of branches you want to split your flow into. The flow will be split in equal proportions.

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: Wait
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
Wait
The Wait flow control component lets you halt the flow for the specified interval of time.

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: If
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
If
The If flow control component lets you create a condition check point. If the condition is verified, the user will proceed to the "true" route, if not, the user will proceed to the "false" route.

automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.title: Exit conditions
automations/the-key-component-of-an-auto.body:
Exit conditions
Exit conditions are conditions that -if verified at any moment of the automation- will cause the user to exit the automation regardless of his/her current position in the automation.
You can add exit conditions by clicking on the "Add Exit condition" button in the bottom right corner of the builder.

automations/lifecycle-of-an-automation.h.title: Lifecycle of an automation
automations/lifecycle-of-an-automation.h.body:
Lifecycle of an automation
When you click on "Builder", you will start creating an automation. However it will remain in "Draft" state until you first click the "Save" button on the top right corner of the builder.

Once you click on "Save" you will be asked to give your automation a name.

Once it is saved, the automation is in put in "Paused" state. You will have the possibility to activate it (which will make it live) or edit it (which will allow you to modify it).

If you activate an automation, it is put in "Active" state and is therefore live. You can pause it by clicking on the "Pause" button on the top right corner of the builder.

In the "Paused" or "Active" states, you will have some additional actions available on some of the components, just click on one and discover what you can do.

Back in the Automation list, the status column will let you see instantly which of your automations are paused (orange) and which are active (green).

On the end of each row, you can find links to edit or delete the related automation.
